title: Ask HN: How do you share your salaries?
text:
Do you share your salaries among your team? How do you go about it?

We're finding some pretty large pay disparities among our team and would like to compile an open sheet of salaries and bonuses. Some of our executive management has been very vocally against this and there are fears of retaliation. We'd like to be careful in how we go about this.

Ask HN: Recommend video streaming CDN service
text:
I would like to provide users with video streaming but would like to avoid the hustle of running the infrastructure.

Can you recommend a cheap CDN service for video streaming?

The way I imagine it is that a user will request a video stream instance, I will set it up via automated API calls and provide the user with access details for OBS(or similar software). The user then starts the video stream. Other users/audience will be able to watch it on my platform via embedded video player that will be streaming the video from this video cdn service. And I will be charged per use(although I would prefer something more predictable, rather than actual per-data pricing to not go bankrupt in case of sudden extreme interest in some video stream).

Ask HN: A career in desktop (C++) or web app development-which would you choose?
text: I've just graduated and am job hunting. I've focused my search on web dev roles, yet much to my surprise recruiters are contacting me more often about desktop development jobs (C++). This surprises me as I'm a competent web developer but have only minimal C++ experience. I'm currently interviewing for both C++ and web dev roles at different companies. I may need to choose between these two areas soon, and this decision feels consequential as it may determine the direction of my career. I'm seeking advice about which path to take. Which would you choose? Which has the brightest future in 2022?

The DOJ just called me about Adobe/Figma merger
text:
I only hire people who use the software. I couldn't answer all of their questions. So I thought you guys might be able to help. 1. What is the cost of each and how has that changed over time? 2. Are there any true alternatives to these two? 3. Has Adobe innovated more as a result of the competition with Figma? 4. Anything else you could contribute to show how a user/consumer would be harmed by the merger.

Thanks for your help.

title: Ask HN: What tech would you use to build Instagram with in 2022?
text:
Hours ago, I tried opening a new Instagram account to use as a visual diary / highlight of my day (I’ve been exploring the outside world for 15km+ everyday for over a year now). I recently hit an age milestone and intending to be quite anti-social with that account, insofar that I just post pictures that I like or capture my mood for day, rather than attempting to impress people with how great my life is.

Anyways, Instagram’s intelligent AI/ML kicked in and asked me to upload a selfie holding up a verification code. That’s not worth the effort. I think I’m just going to build my own visual diary tool. I won’t need all the bells and whistles of Instagram. Just an app where I can upload a picture, crop it into a square. In fact, the main features I had in mind are that there are no features. Heck, maybe downgrade the image resolution to force my brain memory muscle to work and avoid myopia. I’m thinking just a small monolith in Go and store the images on S3. I’m okay with a public bucket as I’m not intending on posting anything I don’t want people to see.

Thoughts on that “tech stack” I had in mind? What would you use if the engineering goal is simplicity and pragmatism? Don’t really care to wrestle with a new language paradigm right now, although Low-Code/No-code would be compelling. I’m personally less interested from a application logic / control flow / framework perspective, but more from a cloud architecture perspective. What services would you leverage in 2022?

Ask HN: Which C++ book was this?
text:
Please aid a failing memory.

I’m thinking of a book intended to teach C++ —- not a reference book. It would have been in print and available in Barnes and Noble in the US in the summer of 1996. Softcover, and the cover may have been yellow. The book worked through a series of examples over 800 (? maybe) pages focused on building a text editor.

Ring any bells?
